entry.content:
‚ú® Overview of the Programming Content

  1. Different binary search trees;
  2. Different binary search trees II;
  3. Robbery III;
  4. Maximum path sum in a binary tree;

1. Different Binary Search Trees

Given an integer $n$, how many binary search trees are there that consist of exactly $n$ nodes and whose node values are different from $1$ to $n$?

Return the number of binary search trees that satisfy the question.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúDifferent Binary Search Trees‚Äù question is:
$$
G(n) = \sum_{i=1}^{n} G(i - 1) \cdot G(n - i)
$$
In the above equation, there are two definitions:

  1. $G(n)$ÔºöThe number of different binary search trees that can be constructed from a sequence of length $n$;
  2. $F(i,n)$ÔºöThe number of different binary search trees $(1‚â§i‚â§n)$ with $i$ as the root and sequence length $n$;

Firstly, according to the idea in the previous section, the total number of different binary search trees $G(n)$ is the sum of $F(i,n)$ traversing all $i$ $(1‚â§i‚â§n)$.

In other words:
$$
G(n) = \sum_{i=1}^{n}F(i,n)
$$
To edge cases, while the sequence length is $1$(only the root) or $0$ (empty tree), there is only one case, namely:
$$
G(0) = 1 , G(1) = 1
$$

Code(Dynamic Programming)

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n^2)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(n)$

Code(Math)

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(1)$

2. Different Binary Search Trees II;

Question Description

Given an integer $n$, how many binary search trees are there that consist of exactly $n$ nodes and whose node values are different from $1$ to $n$ ?

Return the number of binary search trees that satisfy the question.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúDifferent Binary Search Trees II‚Äù question is:
$$
[start, end] \rightarrow [start,i-1] and [i+1,end]
$$
The key property of a binary search tree is that the value of the root node is greater than the value of all nodes in the left subtree, and less than the value of all nodes in the right subtree, and the left and right subtrees are also binary search trees. Therefore, when generating all feasible binary search trees assuming that the current sequence length is $n$, if we enumerate the value of the root node as $i$, then according to the properties of the binary search tree, we can know that the set of node values in the left subtree is $[i‚Ä¶i-1]$, and the set of node values in the right subtree is [i+1‚Ä¶n].

Compared with the original problem, the generation of the left and right subtrees is a subproblem with a reduced sequence length, so we can think of using the backtracking method to solve this problem.

We define the $generateTrees(start,end)$ function to represent the current value set as $[start,end]$, and return all feasible binary search trees generated by the sequence $[start,end]$. According to the above idea, we consider enumerating the value $i$ in $[start,end]$ as the root of the current binary search tree, then the sequence is divided into two parts:$[start,i-1]$ and $[i+1,end]$.

We recursively call these two parts, $generateTrees(start, i - 1)$ and $generateTrees(i + 1, end)$, to obtain all feasible left subtrees and feasible right subtrees. Then the last step is to select a tree from the set of feasible left subtrees, and then select a tree from the set of feasible right subtrees to splice to the root node, and put the generated binary search tree into the answer array.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O\left( \dfrac{4^n}{\sqrt{n}} \right)$

  • Space Complexity: $O\left( \dfrac{4^n}{\sqrt{n}} \right)$

3. Robbery III

Question Description

The thief has discovered a new area to steal. This area has only one entrance, which we call root.

In addition to the root, each house has only one ‚Äúparent‚Äù house connected to it. After some reconnaissance, the clever thief realized that ‚Äúthe arrangement of all the house in this place is similar to a binary tree.‚Äù If two directly connected houses are robbed on the same night, the houses will automatically alarm.

Given the root of the binary tree. Return the maximum amount that thief can steal without triggering the alarm.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúRobbery III‚Äù is :

$$
\begin{cases}
f[node] = node + g[left]+g[right] \\
g[node] = max(f[left],g[left]) + max(f[right],g[right])
\end{cases}
$$
We can use $f(0)$ to represent the maximum weight sum of nodes selected on the subtree of node $0$ when node $0$ is selected; $g(0)$ represents the maximum weight sum of nodes selected on the subtree of node $0$ when node $0$ is not selected; $l$ and $r$ represent the left and right children of $0$.

  1. When $o$ is selected, neither the left nor right child of $o$ can be selected. Therefore, the maximum weight of the selected points on the subtree when $o$ is selected is the sum of the maximum weight of $l$ and $r$ when they are not selected, that is $f(0) = g(l) + g(r)$.
  2. When $o$ is not selected, the left and right children of $o$ can be selected or not. For a specific child $x$ of $o$, its contribution to $o$ is the larger value of the sum of the weights when $x$ is selected and not selected. Therefore, $g(o) = max(f(l),g(l)) + max(f(r),g(r))$.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n)$
  • Space Complexity: $O(n)$

4. Maximum Path Sum in a Binary Tree;

Question Description

A path in a binary tree is defined as a sequence of nodes with an edge between each pair of adjacent nodes. The same node appears at most once in a path sequence. The path contains at least one node and does not necessarily pass through the root node.

The path sum is the sum of the values of the nodes in the path.

Given a binary tree root node, return its maximum path sum.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúMaximum Path Sum in a Binary Tree‚Äù question is:
$$
\begin{cases}
leftGain = max(maxGain(node->left),0) \\
rightGain = max(maxGain(node->right),0)
\end{cases}
$$
$$
priceNewpath = node + leftGain + rightGain
$$

To calculate the maximum contribution value of a node in a binary tree, specifically, to find a path starting from the node in the subtree with the node as the root node, so that the sum of the node values on the path is maximized.

The function is calculated as follows.

  1. The maximum contribution of an empty node is equal to $0$;
  2. The maximum contribution of a non-empty node is equal to the sum of the node value and the maximum contribution of its child nodes (for leaf nodes, the maximum contribution is equal to the node value).

After getting the maximum contribution value of each node according to the function $maxGain$, how to get the maximum path sum of the binary tree? For a node in a binary tree, the maximum path sum of the node depends on the value of the node and the maximum contribution values of the left and right child nodes of the node. If the maximum contribution value of the child node is positive, it is included in the maximum path sum of the node, otherwise it is not included in the maximum path sum of the node. Maintain a global variable $maxSum$ to store the maximum path sum, update the value of $maxSum$ during the recursive process, and the final value of $maxSum$ is the maximum path sum in the binary tree.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(n)$

entry.title: Dynamic Programming(6)---Buy and Sell Stocks
entry.content:
‚ú® Overview of the Programming Content

  1. Best time to buy and sell stocks;
  2. Best time to buy and sell stocks II;
  3. Best time to buy and sell stocks III;
  4. Best time to buy and sell stocks IV;
  5. Best time to buy and sell stocks including handling fee;
  6. Maximum profit of stocks;

Recommended editing tool: **Typora **(Markdown editing)

1. Best Time to Sell Stocks

Given an array $prices$, whose $i$-th element $prices[i]$ represents the price of a given stock on the $i$th day.

You can only choose to buy this stock on a certain day and choose to sell it on a different day in the future. Design an algorithm to calculate the maximum profit you can get.

Return the maximum profit you can get from this transaction. If you cannot get any profit, return $0$.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúBest time to sell stocks‚Äù question is:
$$
maxProfit = prices[i] - minprice
$$
In this question, we only need to use a variable to record the historical lowest price $minprice$, and we can assume that out stock was bought on that day. Then the profit we can get from selling the stock on the $i$th day is $prices[i] - minprice$.

Therefore, we only need to traverse the price array once, record the historical lowest point, and then consider this question every day: If I bought it at the historical lowest point, how much money can I make by selling it today? when all the days are considered, we get the best answer.

Code(One Pass)

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n^2)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(1)$

Code(One Pass)

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(1)$

2. Best Time to Sell Stocks II

Question Description

Given an integer array $prices$, where $prices[i]$ represents the price of a stock on day $i$.

Once each day, you can decide whether to buy and/or sell the stock. You can only hold at most one share of the stock at any time. You can also buy and then sell on the same day.

Return the maximum profit you can make.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúBest time to sell stocks II‚Äù question is:
$$
\begin{cases}
dp[i][0] = max(dp[i-1][0],dp[i-1][1] + prices[i])\\
dp[i][1] = max(dp[i-1][1],dp[i-1][0] - prices[0])
\end{cases}
$$
In the above equation, we use $‚Äô0‚Äô$ to represent ‚ÄòNo stock hold‚Äô, and use $‚Äô1‚Äô$ to represent ‚Äòstock hold‚Äô.

Define the state $dp[i][0]$ to represent the maximum profit of holding no stock after the $i$th day of trading, and $dp[i][1]$ to represent the maximum profit of holding a stock after the $i$th day of trading($i$ starts at $0$).

The boundary conditions:
$$
\begin{cases}
dp[0][0] = 0 \\
dp[0][1] = - prices[0]
\end{cases}
$$

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(n)$

3. Best Time to Buy and Sell Stocks III

Question Description

Given an array whose $i$th elements is the price of a given stock on the $i$th day.

Design an algorithm to calculate the maximum profit you can make. You can complete at most two trades.

Note: You cannot participate in multiple trades at the same time(you must sell the previous stock before buying it again).

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúBest Time to Buy and Sell Stocks III‚Äù is :

$$
\begin{cases}
dp[i][k][0] = max(dp[i-1][k][0],dp[i-1][k][1] + prices[i]) \\
dp[i][k][1] = max(dp[i-1][k][1],dp[i-1][k-1][0] - prices[i])
\end{cases}
$$
In the above equation, we use $‚Äô0‚Äô$ to represent ‚ÄòNo stock hold‚Äô, and use $‚Äô1‚Äô$ to represent ‚Äòstock hold‚Äô.

Moreover, $dp[i][k][s]$ means: ‚ÄúOn the $i$th day, there are at most $k$ transactions and the maximum profit when the holding status is $s(0/1)$‚Äù.

The boundary conditions:
$$
\begin{cases}
dp[0][k][0] = 0,& \text{k = 0,1,2}\\
dp[0][k][1] = - prices[i],& \text{k = 0,1,2}
\end{cases}
$$
While the question acquire ‚ÄúYou can complete at most two trades‚Äù, $k$ must satisfy $k < 3$.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n)$
  • Space Complexity: $O(n)$

4. Best Time to Sell Stocks IV

Question Description

Given an integer array $prices$ and an integer $k$, where $prices[i]$ represents the price of a stock on day $i$.

Design an algorithm to calculate the maximum profit you can make. You can complete at most $k$ trades. That is, you can buy at most $k$ times and sell at most $k$ times.

Note: You cannot participate in multiple trades at the same time(you must sell the previous stock before buying it again).

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúBest time to sell stocks IV‚Äù question is:
$$
\begin{cases}
dp[i][k][0] = max(dp[i-1][k][0],dp[i-1][k][1] + prices[i]) \\
dp[i][k][1] = max(dp[i-1][k][1],dp[i-1][k-1][0] - prices[i])
\end{cases}
$$
In the above equation, we use $‚Äô0‚Äô$ to represent ‚ÄòNo stock hold‚Äô, and use $‚Äô1‚Äô$ to represent ‚Äòstock hold‚Äô.

Moreover, $dp[i][k][s]$ means: ‚ÄúOn the $i$th day, there are at most $k$ transactions and the maximum profit when the holding status is $s(0/1)$‚Äù.

The boundary conditions:
$$
\begin{cases}
dp[0][k][0] = 0,& \text{k < m+1}\\
dp[0][k][1] = - prices[i],& \text{k < m+1}
\end{cases}
$$
While the question acquire ‚ÄúYou can complete at most two trades‚Äù, $k$ must satisfy $k < m+1$.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n \times k)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(n \times k)$

5. Best Time to Buy and Sell Stocks Including Freeze Period

Question Description

Given an integer array $prices$, where $prices[i]$ represents the stock price on the $i$th day.

Design an algorithm to calculate the maximum profit. You can complete as many transactions as possible(buy and sell a stock multiple times) under the following constraints:

After selling a stock, you cannot but it back the next day(i.e. the freezing period is 1 day).

Note: You cannot participate in multiple transactions at the same time(you must sell the previous stock before buying it again).

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúBest time to buy and sell stocks including freeze period‚Äù question is:
$$
\begin{cases}
dp[i][0] = max(dp[i-1][0],dp[i-1][1] - prices[i]) \\
dp[i][1] = max(dp[i-1][1],dp[i-1][2])\\
dp[i][2] = dp[i][0] + prices[i]
\end{cases}
$$
The boundary conditions:
$$
\begin{cases}
dp[0][0] = - prices[i]\\
dp[0][1] = 0 \\
dp[0][2] = 0
\end{cases}
$$
In the above equation, we divide this question into three different conditions.

We use $‚Äô0‚Äô$ to represent ‚Äòstock hold‚Äô, and use $‚Äô1‚Äô$ to represent ‚Äòno stock hold but in the non-freezing period‚Äô and use $‚Äô2‚Äô$ to represent ‚Äòno stock hold and in the freezing period‚Äô.

Moreover, $dp[i][s]$ means: ‚ÄúOn the $i$th day, the maximum profit when the holding status is $s(0/1/2)$‚Äù.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n)$
  • Space Complexity: $O(n)$

6. The Best Time to Buy and Sell Stocks with Commission

Question Description

Given an integer array $prices$, where $prices[i]$ represents the stock prices on the $i$th day; the integer fee represents the commission for trading stocks.

You can complete transactions as many times as you want, but you need to pay a commission for each transaction. If you have already bought a stock, you cannot continue to buy stocks before selling it.

Return the maximum profit.

Note: A transaction here refers to the entire process of buying, holding and selling stocks. You only need to pay a commission once for each transaction.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúBest time to buy and sell stocks with commission‚Äù question is:
$$
\begin{cases}
dp[i][0] = max(dp[i-1][0],dp[i-1][1] + prices[i] - fee) \\
dp[i][1] = max(dp[i-1][1],dp[i-1][0] - prices[i])
\end{cases}
$$
The boundary conditions:
$$
\begin{cases}
dp[0][0] = 0\\
dp[0][1] = - prices[i]
\end{cases}
$$

Details

Why is the transaction fee subtracted when ‚Äòselling‚Äô instead of added when ‚Äòbuying‚Äô?

From the semantics of the transaction:

  • The handling fee is incurred in conjunction with a complete ‚Äúbuy + sell‚Äù and is only charged once;
  • It is generally believed that only when selling is the transaction truly completed and the handling fee needs to be paid.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(n)$

entry.title: Dynamic Programming(5)---Longest Common Subsequence
entry.content:
‚ú® Overview of the Programming Content

  1. Longest common subsequence;
  2. Non-intersecting lines;
  3. Minimum number of insertions to make a string a palindrome;

Recommended editing tool: **Typora **(Markdown editing)

1. Longest Common Sequence

Given two strings $text_1$ and $text_2$, return the length of the longest common subsequence of the two strings. If there is no common subsequences, return 0.

A subsequence of a string is a new string that is formed by deleting some characters(or none) from the original string without changing the relative order of the characters.

For example, ‚Äúace‚Äù is a subsequence of ‚Äúabcde‚Äù, but ‚Äúaec‚Äù is not a subsequence of ‚Äúabcde‚Äù. A common subsequence of two strings is a subsequence that the two strings have in common.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúLongest common sequence‚Äù question is:
$$
dp[i][j]=
\begin{cases}
dp[i-1][j-1] + 1,& text_1[i-1] = text_2[j-1]\\
max(dp[i-1][j],dp[i][j-1]),&text_1[i-1] ‚â† text_2[j-1]
\end{cases}
$$
The longest common subsequence problem is a typical two-dimensional dynamic programming problem.

Assume that the lengths of the strings $text_1$ and $text_2$ are $m$ and $n$ respectively, create a two-dimensional array $dp$ with $m+1$ rows and $n+1$ columns, where $dp[i][j]$ represents the length of the longest common subsequence of $text_1 [0:i]$ and $text_2 [0:j]$.

In the above representation, $text_1[0:i]$ represents the prefix of $text_1$ with length $i$ and $text_2[0:j]$ represents the prefix of $text_2$ with length $j$.

Consider the edge case of dynamic programmingÔºö
$$
\begin{cases}
dp[0][j] = 0,& \text{while } i = 0 \text{ and } 0 ‚â§ j ‚â§ n\\
dp[i][0] = 0,& \text{while } j = 0 \text{ and } 0 ‚â§ i ‚â§ n
\end{cases}
$$

Details

Why we use ‚Äú$text_1[i-1] = text_2[j-1]$‚Äù but not ‚Äú$text_1[i] = text_2[j]$‚Äù?

The character $dp[i][j]$ represents the longest common subsequence of the first $i$ characters of $text_1$ and the first $j$ characters of $text_2$.

For example, $dp[i][1]$ represents the relationship between $text_1[0]$ and $text_2[0]$.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(m \times n)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(m \times n)$

2. Non-Intersecting Lines

Question Description

Write the integers in $nums_1$ and $nums_2$ in the given order on two separate horizontal lines.

Now, we can draw lines connecting two numbers $nums_1[i]$ and $nums_2[j]$, where

  • $nums_1[i] == nums_2[j]$;
  • and the lines do not intersect any other lines (not horizontal lines).

Note that lines cannot intersect even at their endpoints : each number can belong to only one line.

Draw lines in this way and return the maximum number of lines that can be drawn.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúNon-intersecting lines‚Äù question is:
$$
dp[i][j]=
\begin{cases}
dp[i-1][j-1] + 1,& text_1[i-1] = text_2[j-1]\\
max(dp[i-1][j],dp[i][j-1]),&text_1[i-1] ‚â† text_2[j-1]
\end{cases}
$$
Actually ,the question ‚ÄúLongest common sequence‚Äù and ‚ÄúNon-intersecting lines‚Äù question are the same one.

Once you realize this problem, you can solve it in the same way.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(m \times n)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(m \times n)$

3. Minimum Number of Insertions Required to Make a String a Palindrome

Question Description

Given a string $s$, you can insert any character at any position in the string with each operation.

Please return the minimum number of operations required to make $s$ a palindrome.

A palindrome is a string that is the same when read forwards and backwards.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúMinimum Number of Intersections Required to Make a String a Palindrome‚Äù is :

Minimum Number of Intersections = String length - Longest common subsequence with reversed string

So that this problem is the variations of the longest common subsequence problem.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n^2)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(n^2)$

entry.title: Dynamic Programming(4)---Longest Increasing Subsequence
entry.content:
‚ú® Overview of the Programming Content

  1. Longest increasing subsequence;
  2. Number of longest increasing subsequences;
  3. Longest chain of pairs of numbers;
  4. Longest fixed difference subsequences;
  5. Longest arithmetic progression;
  6. Russian doll envelope problem;
  7. Find the longest valid obstacle race route to each position;

Recommended editing tool: **Typora **(Markdown editing)

1. Longest Increasing Subsequence

Given an array of integers $nums$, find the length of the longest strictly increasing subsequence in it.

A subsequence is a sequence derived from an array by removing(or not removing) elements from the array without changing the order of the remaining elements. For example, $[3,6,2,7]$ is a subsequence of the array $[0,3,1,6,2,2,7]$.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúLongest increasing subsequence‚Äù question is:
$$
dp[i] = max(dp[j]) + 1, 0 ‚â§ j < i,\text{and}, num[j] < num[i]
$$
Define $dp[i]$ as the length of the longest ascending subsequence ending with the $i$th digit considering the first $i$ elements. Note that $nums[i]$ must be selected.

Since $dp[j]$ represents the longest increasing subsequence ending with $nums[j]$ in $nums[0‚Ä¶j]$, if we can transfer from the state of $dp[j]$, then $nums[i]$ must be greater than $nums[j]$,so that $nums[i]$ can be placed after $nums[j]$ to form a longer increasing subsequence.

Finally, the longest ascending subsequence of the entire array is the maximum value among all $dp[j]$.
$$
\text{LIS}_{\text{length}} = \max(dp[i]),\quad \text{while} \quad 0 \leq i < n
$$
The answer is $max(dp)$.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n^2)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(n)$

2. The Number of the Longest Increasing Subsequence

Question Description

Given an unsorted integer array $nums$, return the number of the longest increasing subsequence.

Note that this sequence must be strictly increasing.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúThe number of the longest increasing subsequence‚Äù question is:
$$
cnt(i)=
\begin{cases}
cnt(j),& \text{dp(i) < dp(j) + 1}\\
cnt(i) + cnt(j),dp(i,j-1)),&\text{dp(i) ‚â• dp(j)}
\end{cases}
$$
For $cnt[i]$, it is equal to the sum of all $cnt[j]$ that satisfy $dp[j] + 1 = dp[i]$. When implementing the code, we can count the value of $cnt[i]$ while calculating $dp[i]$.

Detail

When calculating the final answer $ans$, we should use $ans += cnt[i]$ not $ans = cnt[i]$.

Assuming that the first element that meets the condition is traversed, $ans = cnt[i]$ is directly assigned a value. If another $i$ that meets the condition is encountered later, it will be overwritten and the previous count will be lost.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n^2)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(n)$

3. Longest Pair Chain

Question Description

Given an array pairs consisting of $n$ pairs, where $pairs[i] = [left_i,right_i]$ and $left_i < right_i$.

Now, we define a following relation, that is, a pair $p_2 = [c,d]$ can follow $p_1 = [a,b]$ if and only if $b < c$.

We use this form to construct a pair chain.

Find and return the length of the longest pair chain that can be formed.

You do not need to use all the pairs. You can choose some of them in any order to construct.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúLongest Pair Chain‚Äù is
$$
dp(i) = max(dp(i),dp(j) + 1), \text{while}, pairs[i][0] > pairs[j][1]
$$

Details

Before the comparison, you should $sort$ the array while this question is not sorted in the order of the array.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n^2)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(n)$

4. Longest Arithmetic Subsequence

Question Description

Given an integer array $arr$ and an integer difference, find and return the length of the longest arithmetic subsequence in $arr$ where the difference between adjacent elements is equal to difference.

A subsequence is a sequence derived from $arr$ by deleting some elements or not deleting any elements without changing the order of the remaining elements.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúLongest arithmetic subsequence‚Äù is:
$$
dp(i) = max(dp(i),dp(j)+1), \text{ if },arr(i) - arr(j) = difference
$$
We traverse $arr$ from left to right and calculate the length of the longest arithmetic subsequence ending with $arr[i]$, and take the maximum of all lengths to get the answer.

Let $dp[i]$ represent the length of the longest arithmetic subsequence ending with $arr[i]$. We can find the element on the left side of $arr[i]$ that satisfies $arr[j] = arr[i] - d$, and add $arr[i]$ to the end of the longest arithmetic subsequence ending with $arr[j]$.

In this way, $dp[i]$ can be rescursively calculated from $dp[j]$.

The final answer is $max(dp)$.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n^2)$
  • Space Complexity: $O(n)$

The above code is still to complex, we can use ‚ÄúHash table method‚Äù to simplify the process.

The cores equation of the following method is :
$$
dp[num] = dp[num - difference] + 1
$$

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(n)$

5. Longest Arithmetic Sequence

Question Description

Given an integer array $nums$, return the length of the longest arithmetic subsequence in $nums$.

Recall that a subsequence of $nums$ is a list $nums[i_1],nums[i_2],‚Ä¶,nums[i_k]$, with $0 ‚â§ i_1 < i_2 < ‚Ä¶ < i_k ‚â§ nums.length - 1$. And a sequence $seq$ is arithmetic if the values of $seq[i+1]-seq[i](0 ‚â§ i < seq.length - 1)$ are all the same.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúLongest Arithmetic Sequence‚Äù is:
$$
f[i][d] = f[j].count[d] \text{ ? } f[j][d] + 1 : 2
$$
Note that $f[i][d][num]$ means using the elements in the array $nums$ with subscripts less than or equal to $i$ to construct an arithmetic sequence with a common difference of $d$, and the maximum length of the arithmetic sequence when the last element is $num$.

When performing state transition, we consider whether to add the current $i$th element as the last item in the arithmetic progression.

Use an outer loop to enumerate $d$, and in the inner loop, only two state transitions are required:

  1. $$
    f[nums[i]] \leftarrow f[nums[i] - d] + 1
    $$

  2. $$
    f[nums[i]] \leftarrow 1
    $$

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n^2)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(n^2$)

6. Russian Doll Envelope Problem

Question Description

Given a two-dimensional integer array $envelopes$, where $envelopes[i] = [w_i, h_i]$, represents the width and height of the $i$th envelope.

When the width and height of another envelope are larger than this envelope can be put into another envelope, just like a Russian doll.

Please calculate how many envelopes can form a set of ‚ÄúRussian doll‚Äù envelopes(that is, one envelope can be put into another envelope).

Note : Envelope rotation is not allowed.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúRussian doll envelope problem‚Äù question is:
$$
f[i] = \max_{j<i \land h_j<h_i} { f[j] } + 1
$$
Following the LIS method, we can also get the below codes.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n^2)$
  • Space Complexity: $O(n)$

However, the above code is too complex, so that we can consider ‚ÄúDynamic programming based on binary search‚Äù.

Let $f[j]$ represent the minimum value of the last element of the longest strictly increasing subsequence of length $j$ that can be formed by the first $i$ elements of $h$. If there is no longest strictly increasing subsequence of length $j$, the corresponding $f$ value is undefined.

Within the defined range, it can be seen that the $f$ value is strictly monotonically increasing, because the longer the subsequence, the larger the last element.

When performing state transition, we consider the current element $h$:

  1. If $h_i$ is greater than the maximum value in $f$, then $h_i$ can be connected to the maximum value in $f$ to form a longer strictly increasing subsequence;

  2. Otherwise, we find the largest element in $f[j_0]$ in $f$ that is strictly smaller than $h_i$,that is $f[j_0] < h_i ‚â§ f[j_0 + 1]$, then $h_i$ can be connected after $f[j_0]$ to form a strictly increasing subsequence of length $j$. So $f[j_0 + 1]$ need to be updated :
    $$
    f[j_0 + 1] = h_i
    $$

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(nlogn)$
  • Space Complexity: $O(n)$

7. Find the Longest Valid Obstacle Course to Each Position

Question Description

You are planning to build some obstacle courses. You are given an array of integers named obstacles with length $n$ and starting at index 0, where $obstacles[i]$ is the height of the $i$th obstacle.

For each index $i$ between $0$ and $n-1$(inclusive), find the length of the longest obstacle course that can be constructed with $obstacles$, provided that:

  • You can choose any number of obstacles with indices between $0$ and $i$, inclusive.
  • The $i$th obstacle must be included in the course.
  • You must place the obstacles in the order they appear in obstacles.
  • Except for the first obstacle, each obstacle in the course must be the same height as or taller than the previous one.

Return an answer array $ans$ of length $n$, where $ans[i]$ is the length of the longest obstacle course for index $i$ as described above.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúFind the longest valid obstacle curse to each position‚Äù question is:
$$
dp(i) = max(dp(i),dp(j+1)), \text{ if }, obstacles[i] >= obstacles[j]
$$
Following the LIS method, we can also get the below codes.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n^2)$
  • Space Complexity: $O(n)$

However, the LIS method cost too much time, so that we need to simplify the code.

The we can consider ‚ÄúGreed + Binary Search‚Äù mode.

Algorithm Idea

  • We use a greedy + binary search approach.
  • Maintain a list f where:
    • f[i] represents the smallest possible last height of a valid obstacle course of length i+1.
  • For each obstacle:
    • If its height is greater than or equal to the last element in f, append it to extend the sequence.
    • Otherwise, use binary search (upper_bound) to find the first element greater than num, and replace it to maintain a minimal end value.

This is a modified version of the classical Longest Increasing Subsequence (LIS) algorithm, adapted for non-decreasing sequences.

Algorithm Steps

  1. Initialization:
    • Create array f and add the first obstacle‚Äôs height.
    • Create answer array ans and initialize with 1.
  2. Iterate through obstacles (starting from index 1):
    • For each num = obstacles[i]:
      • If num >= f.back():
        • Append num to f.
        • Update ans[i] = length of f.
      • Else:
        • Use upper_bound in f to find the first element greater than num.
        • Replace that element with num.
        • Update ans[i] = position of replacement + 1.
  3. Return the ans array.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(nlogn)$
  • Space Complexity: $O(n)$

entry.title: Dynamic Programming(3)---Application of Dynamic Programming in Strings
entry.content:
‚ú® Overview of the Programming Content

  1. Longest palindrome substring;
  2. Word splitting;
  3. Longest palindrome subsequence;
  4. Edit distance;
  5. Minimum ASCII deletion sum of two strings;
  6. Distinct subsequences;

Recommended editing tool: **Typora **(Markdown editing)

1. Longest Palindrome Substring

Given a string s, find the longest palindrome substring in ‚Äòs‚Äô.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúLongest palindrome substring‚Äù question is:
$$
P(i,j) = P(i+1,j-1) \land (S_i = S_j)
$$
The boundary conditions:
$$
P(i,i) =
\begin{cases}
true,& \text{1-letter substrings are palindromes}\\
S_i = S_{i+1},&\text{2-letter substrings are palindromes if both letters are equal}
\end{cases}
$$
We use $P(i,j)$ to indicates whether the string consisting of letters ‚Äò$i$‚Äô to ‚Äò$j$‚Äô of string ‚Äò$s$‚Äô (hereinafter represented as $s[i:j]$ is a palindrome):
$$
P(i,j)=
\begin{cases}
true,& \text{if the substring Si to Sj is a palindrome}\\
false,&\text{other cases}
\end{cases}
$$
There are two possibilities in the ‚Äòother cases‚Äô:

  1. $s[i,j]$ is not a palindrome;
  2. $i > j$, now $s[i,j]$ is illegal;

The answer is $dp[m][n]$.

Details

In the state transfer equation, we transfer from a shorter string to a longer string, so we must pay attention to the loop order of dynamic programming.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n^2)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(n^2)$

2. Word Splitting

Question Description

Given a string $‚Äôs‚Äô$ and a list of strings $‚ÄôwordDict‚Äô$ as a dictionary. Return true if ‚Äò$s$‚Äô can be concatenated using one or more words in the dictionary.

Note: It is not required that all words in the dictionary be used, and words in the dictionary can be reused.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúWord Splitting‚Äù question is:
$$
dp[i] = dp[j] \quad \land \quad \text{check}(s[j..i-1])
$$
In the above equation, $\text{check}(s[j..i-1])$ represent substring $\text{s[j..i-1]}$ whether is in the dictionary.

For the boundary cases, we can define $dp[0] = true$ to represent an empty string and is legal.

We can set $f$ to decide whether to split. The code use $true$ to represent $yes$ and use $false$ to represent $no$.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n^3)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(m + n)$

3. Longest Palindrome Subsequence

Question Description

Given a string ‚Äò$s$‚Äô, find the longest palindrome subsequence in it and return the length of the subsequence.

A subsequence is defined as a sequence formed by deleting some characters or not deleting any characters without changing the order of the remaining characters.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúLongest palindrome subsequence‚Äù is
$$
dp(i,j)=
\begin{cases}
dp(i+1,j-1) + 2,& \text{s(i) = s(j)}\\
max(dp(i+1,j),dp(i,j-1)),&\text{s(i) ‚â† s(j)}
\end{cases}
$$

Boundary Conditions

$$
dp(i,i) = 1
$$

The above equation means ‚Äòany single character can be considered a palindrome‚Äô.

Note: From bottom to top, from left to right, inverted triangle structure design code.

The final answer is $dp(0,n-1)$.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n^2)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(n^2)$

4. Edit Distance

Question Description

Given two words ‚Äò$word1$‚Äô and ‚Äò$word2$‚Äô, please return the minimum number of operations required to convert ‚Äò$word1$‚Äô and ‚Äò$word2$‚Äô.

You can perform the following three operations on a word:

  1. Insert a character;
  2. Delete a character;
  3. Replace a character;

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúEdit Distance‚Äù is:
$$
dp[i][j]=
\begin{cases}
min(dp[i][j-1]+1,dp[i-1][j]+1,dp[i-1][j-1]),& \text{word1[i-1] = word2[j-1]}\\
1+min(dp[i][j-1],dp[i-1][j],dp[i-1][j-1]),&\text{word1[i-1] ‚â† word2[j-1]}
\end{cases}
$$
We use $dp[i][j]$ to denote the edit distance between the first $i$ letters of A and the first $j$ letters of B.

Once we have the values of $dp[i][j-1]$, $dp[i-1][j]$ and $dp[i-1][j-1]$, we can calculate $dp[i][j]$.

  1. $dp[i][j-1]$ is a subproblem of the edit distance between the first $i$ characters of A and the first $j-1$ characters of B. That is, for the $j$th character of B, we add a same character at the end of A, then $dp[i][j]$ can be as small as $dp[i][j-1] + 1$.
  2. $dp[i-1][j]$ is a subproblem of the edit distance between the first $i-1$ characters of A and the first $j$ characters of B. That is, for the $i$th character of A, we add a same character at the end of B, then $dp[i][j]$ can be as small as $dp[i-1][j] + 1$.
  3. $dp[i-1][j-1]$ is a subproblem of the edit distance between the first $i-1$ characters of A and the first $j-1$ characters of B. That is, for the $j$th character of B, we modify the $i$th character of A to make the two same, then $dp[i][j]$ can be as small as $dp[i-1][j-1] + 1$. In particular, if the $i$th character of A the the $j$th character of B are originally the same, then we actually do not need to modify them. In this case, $dp[i][j]$ can be as small as $dp[i-1][j-1]$.

Note

  1. Note that the definition of $dp[i][j]$ is the distance from $word1[0‚Ä¶i-1]$ to $word2[0‚Ä¶j-1]$. So to determine whether the last bit is equal, you must compare $word1[i-1]$ $=$ $word2[j-1]$.
  2. Note that the size of $dp$ is set to $(m+1) \times (n+1)$ because the possibility of an empty set needs to be taken into account. The $n$ in the loop can be replaced by $n+1$.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n \times m)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(n \times m)$

5. Minimum ASCII Deletion Sum of Two Strings

Question Description

Given two string $s1$ and $s2$, return the minimum sum of the ASCII values of the characters that need to be deleted to make the two strings equal.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúEdit Distance‚Äù is:
$$
dp[i][j]=
\begin{cases}
dp[i-1][j-1],& \text{s1[i-1] = s2[j-1]}\\
min(dp[i-1][j]+s1[i-1],dp[i][j-1]+s2[j-1]),&\text{s1[i-1] ‚â† s2[j-1]}
\end{cases}
$$
To get the minimum ASCII delete sum that makes $s1[0:i]$ and $s2[0:j]$ the same, we should take the smaller of the two, so $dp[i][j] = min(dp[i-1][j] + s1[i-1],dp[i][j-1] + s2[j-1])$.

The boundary cases:

  1. If $i = j = 0$:
    $$
    dp[0][0] = 0
    $$

  2. If $i = 0$ and $j > 0$,
    $$
    dp[0][j] = dp[0][j-1] + s2[j-1], 1 ‚â§ j ‚â§ n
    $$

  3. If $j = 0$ and $i > 0$,
    $$
    dp[i][0] = dp[i-1][0] + s1[i-1]Ôºå1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ n
    $$

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n \times m)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(n \times m)$

6. Distinct Subsequences

Question Description

Given two strings ‚Äò$s$‚Äô and ‚Äò$t$‚Äô, count and return the number of occurrences of ‚Äò$t$‚Äô in the subsequences of ‚Äò$s$‚Äô.

The test cases ensures that the result is within the range of a 32-bit signed integer.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúDistinct Subsequences‚Äù question is:
$$
dp(i,j) =
\begin{cases}
dp[i+1][j+1] + dp[i+1][j],& \text{s[i] = t[j]}\\
dp[i+1][j],&\text{s[i] ‚â† t[j]}
\end{cases}
$$
$dp[i][j]$ represents the number of occurrences of $t[j:]$ in the subsequences of $s[i:]$.

In the above representation, $s[i:]$ represents the substring of $s$ from subscript $i$ to the end, and $t[j:]$ represents the substring of $t$ from subscript $j$ to the end.

The boundary cases:

  1. If $j = n$, $t[j:]$ is empty, so that:
    $$
    dp[i][n] = 1 , 0 ‚â§ i ‚â§ m
    $$

  2. If $i = m$ and $j < n$, $s[i:]$ is empty while $t[j:]$ is not empty:
    $$
    dp[m][j] = 0, 0 ‚â§ j ‚â§ n
    $$

Note

Tips to remember:

If you define ‚Äòprefix to the $i$th character‚Äô $\rightarrow$ remember to use $i-1$ index;

If you define ‚Äòsuffix starting from the $i$th position‚Äô$\rightarrow$ use $i$ directly.

In prefix form, we define:

$dp[i][j]$ means using the prefix of $s[0‚Ä¶i-1]$ and $t[0‚Ä¶j-1]$. So the comparison is: $s[i-1]$ and $t[j-1]$.

In suffix form, we define:

$dp[i][j]$ means using the suffix of $s[i:]$ and $t[j:]$. So the comparison isÔºö $s[i]$ and $t[j]$.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(m \times n)$
  • Space Complexity: $O(m \times n)$

entry.title: Dynamic Programming(2)---Matrix Types
entry.content:
‚ú® Overview of the Programming Content

  1. Different paths;
  2. Minimum path sum;
  3. Different path II;
  4. Minimum path sum of triangle;
  5. Minimum sum of descending path;
  6. Maximum square;

Recommended editing tool: **Typora **(Markdown editing)

1. Different Paths

Question Description:

A robot is located at the top left corner of an $m \times n$ grid(the starting point is marked as ‚ÄúStart‚Äù in the figure below);

The robot can only move one step down or one step to the right at a time. The robot tires to reach the bottom right corner of the grid(marked as ‚ÄúFinish‚Äù in the figure below).

How many different paths are there in total?

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúDifferent paths‚Äù question is:
$$
f(i,j) = f(i-1,j) + f(i,j-1)
$$
We can use $f(i,j)$ to represent the number of different paths from the top left corner to the end, while the range of $i$ is $[0,m)$ and $j$ is $[0,n)$.

While we can only move one step downward go or to the right, if you want to reach location $(i,j)$, you can move one step downward from $(i-1,j)$ or move one step to the right from $(i,j-1)$.

Therefore, the number of paths to reach position $(i,j)$ is the sum of the number of paths above.

In programming, we should consider the conditions including $i = 0$ as $f(i-1,j)$ and $f(i,j-1)$.

Initial condition is $f(0,0) = 1$, which means move from top left corner to top left corner.

The final answer is $f(m-1,n-1)$.

Details

To facilitate code writing, we can set all $f(0,j)$ and $f(i,0)$ as boundary conditions, and their values are all 1.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(m \times n)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(m \times n)$

2. Minimum Path Sum

Question Description

Given an $m \times n$ grid containing non-negative integers, find a path from the upper left corner to the lower right corner so that the sum of the numbers on the path is the smallest.

Note: You can only move down or right one step at a time.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúMinimum Path Sum‚Äù question is:
$$
f(i,j) = grid(i,j) + min(f(i-1,j),f(i,j-1))
$$
We use $f(i,j)$ to represent the minimum path sum at location $(i,j)$. The above equation means the minimum path sum of position $(i,j)$ is equal to the minimum path sum of the previous position plus the value of position $(i,j)$.

However, we should consider the boundary conditions including the first row and the first column.

For this question, we should divide it into three different conditions:

  1. If $i > 0$ and $j = 0$, $f(i,0) = f(i-1,0) + grid(i,0)$;
  2. If $i = 0$ and $j > 0$, $f(0,j) = f(0,j-1) + grid(0,j)$;
  3. If $i > 0$ and $j > 0$, $f(i,j) = grid(i,j) + min(f(i-1,j),f(i,j-1))$;

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(m \times n)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(m \times n)$

3. Different Path II;

Question Description

Given an ‚Äú$m \times n$‚Äù integer array $grid$. A robot is initially located at the upper left corner(i.e. $grid[0][0]$). The robot attempts to move to the lower right corner(i.e. $grid[m-1][n-1]$). The robot can only move one step down or one step to the right at a time.

Obstacles and empty positions in the $grid$ are represented by 1 and 0 respectively. The robot‚Äôs movement path cannot contain any squares with obstacles.

Return the number of different paths that the robot can take to reach the lower right corner.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúDifferent Paths II‚Äù is
$$
f(i,j)=
\begin{cases}
0,& \text{if obstacleGrid[i][j] = 1}\\
f(i-1,j) + f(i,j-1),&\text{if obstacleGrid[i][j] = 0}
\end{cases}
$$
We use $f(i,j)$ to represent the total number of paths from coordinate $(0,0)$ to coordinate $(i,j)$.

The above equation means: if there is an obstacle, there is no path that can get to this location.

However, if there is no obstacle, the total number of paths in location $(i,j)$ is equal to the sum of location $(i-1,j)$ and $(i,j-1)$.

What‚Äôs more, we should consider two special conditions: the first rows and the first columns.

All in all, we can summary three equations as follows:

  1. if $i>0$ and $j = 0$ , we can get
    $$
    f(i,0)=
    \begin{cases}
    break, & \text{if obstacleGrid[i][0] = 1}\\
    1,&\text{if obstacleGrid[i][0] = 0}
    \end{cases}
    $$

  2. if $i = 0$ and $j > 0$, we can get
    $$
    f(0,j)=
    \begin{cases}
    break, & \text{if obstacleGrid[0][j] = 1}\\
    1,&\text{if obstacleGrid[0][j] = 0}
    \end{cases}
    $$

  3. if $i > 0$ and $j > 0$, we can get
    $$
    f(i,j)=
    \begin{cases}
    0,& \text{if obstacleGrid[i][j] = 1}\\
    f(i-1,j) + f(i,j-1),&\text{if obstacleGrid[i][j] = 0}
    \end{cases}
    $$

Boundary Conditions

$$
f(0,0)=
\begin{cases}
0, & \text{if obstacleGrid[0][0] = 1}\\
1,&\text{if obstacleGrid[0][0] = 0}
\end{cases}
$$

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(m \times n)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(m \times n)$

4. Minimum Path Sum of Triangle

Question Description

Given a triangle matrix, find the minimum path sum from top to bottom.

Each step can only move to adjacent nodes in the next row. Adjacent node means the two nodes which have the same subscripts as the previous node or equal to the subscript of the previous node +1. That is if you are at subscript $i$ in the current row, then the next step can move to subscript $i$ or $i-1$ in the next row.

Analysis

The core idea of ‚ÄúMinimum Path‚Äù problem is ‚Äúfrom the bottom to the top‚Äù.

The core equation of ‚ÄúThe Minimum Path of the Triangle‚Äù is:
$$
dp(i,j) = triangle(i,j) + min(dp(j),dp(j+1))
$$
Calculate the path sum from the second to last line, and make sure the data of each iteration is not polluted.

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n^2)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(n)$

5. Minimum Sum of Descending Path;

Question Description

Give you an $n \times n$ square array of integers matrix, find and return the minimum sum of a descending path through the matrix.

The descending path can start from any element in the first row and select an element from each row. The element selected int the next row is at most one column away from the element selected in the current row(i.e. the first element directly below or diagonally to the left or right). Specifically, the next element at position $(row, col)$ should be $(row+1,col-1)$,$(row + 1, col)$, or $(row + 1, col + 1)$.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúThe Minimum Sum of Descending Paths‚Äù is
$$
dp(i,j) = matrix(i,j) + min(dp(j-1),dp(j),dp(j+1))
$$
However, $j-1$ and $j + 1$ must stay within the matrix boundaries.

From the above words, we should divide this problem into three different conditions:

  1. If $j = 0$, we get $dp(i,j) = matrix(i,j) + min(dp(j),dp(j+1))$;
  2. If $j = n-1$, we get $dp(i,j) = matrix(i,j) + min(dp(j-1),dp(j))$;
  3. If $0 < j < n-1$, we get $dp(i,j) = matrix(i,j) + min(dp(j-1),dp(j),dp(j+1))$;

We solve the problem using a bottom-up approach.

Then the final answer $res = min(dp)$ .

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n^2)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(n)$

6. Maximum Square

Question Description

In a 2D matrix of ‚Äò0‚Äô and ‚Äò1‚Äô, find the largest square containing only ‚Äò1‚Äô and return its area.

Analysis

The core equation of ‚ÄúMaximum Square‚Äù question is:
$$
dp(i,j) = min(dp(i-1,j),dp(i-1,j-1),dp(i,j-1)) + 1
$$
In this question, there are three different conditions.

  1. If $i > 0$ and $j = 0$ , we can get
    $$
    dp(i,0)=
    \begin{cases}
    0, & \text{if obstacleGrid[i][0] = 0}\\
    1,&\text{if obstacleGrid[i][0] = 1}
    \end{cases}
    $$

  2. If $i = 0$ and $j > 0$, we can get
    $$
    dp(0,j)=
    \begin{cases}
    0, & \text{if obstacleGrid[0][j] = 0}\\
    1,&\text{if obstacleGrid[0][j] = 1}
    \end{cases}
    $$

  3. If $i > 0$ and $j > 0$, we can get
    $$
    dp(i,j) = min(dp(i-1,j),dp(i-1,j-1),dp(i,j-1)) + 1
    $$

Code

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(m \times n)$
  • Space Complexity: $O(m \times n)$

entry.title: Dynamic Programming(1)---Fibonacci Types
entry.content:
‚ú® Overview of the Programming Content

  1. Climb stairs;
  2. Fibonacci number;
  3. Nth Tibonacci number;
  4. Climb stairs with minimum cost;
  5. Robbery;
  6. Delete and gain points;

Recommended editing tool: **Typora **(Markdown editing)

1. Climb Stairs

Question Description:

Suppose you are climbing a staircase. It takes $n$ steps to reach the top. Each time you can climb 1 or 2 steps. How many different ways can you climb to the top?

Analyse

We can use $f(x)$ to represent the ‚Äò$x$‚Äô step, consider the last step maybe 1 or 2 steps, we can list the following formula:
$$
\begin{equation}
f(x) = f(x-1) + f(x-2)
\end{equation}
$$
It means that the number of solutions to climb the $x$th step is the sum of the number of solutions to climb the $(x-1)$th step and the number of solutions to climb the $(x-2)$th step. It is easy to understand, because we can only climb 1 or 2 steps at a time, so $f(x)$ can only be transferred from $f(x-1)$ and $f(x-2)$. To count the total number of solutions here, we need to sum the contributions of these two items.

In other words, in my opinion, there are two usual ways to solve basic dynamic questions: finding patterns or solving general formulas. Then, it is easy to transfer the idea into C++ codes.

There are two methods to deal with this problem.

Iteration

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(1)$

Recursion

2. Fibonacci Number

Question Description

The sequence of Fibonacci numbers (usually denoted by $F(n)$) is called the Fibonacci sequence. The sequence starts with 0 and 1. and each subsequent number is the sum of the previous two numbers. That is:
$$
F(0) = 0, \quad F(1) = 1
$$

$$
F(n) = F(n - 1) + F(n - 2), \quad \text{ÂÖ∂‰∏≠ } n > 1
$$

Given the number $n$, please calculate $F(n)$.

Analyse

This question is similar with the first one - ‚ÄòClimb Stairs‚Äô.

The boundary conditions of Fibonacci Number are $F(0) = 0$ and $F(1) = 1$. When $n > 1$, the sum of each term is equal to the sum of the previous two terms, so there is the following recursive relationship:
$$
F(n) = F(n-1) + F(n-2)
$$
Since the Fibonacci numbers have a recursive relationship, dynamic programming can be used to solve them. The state transition equation of dynamic programming is the above recursive relationship, and the boundary conditions are $F(0)$ and $F(1)$.

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(1)$

3. Nth Tibonacci number

Question Description

The Tibonacci sequence $(T_n)$ is defined as follows:

$$
T_0 = 0,\quad T_1 = 1,\quad T_2 = 1
$$

and:

$$
T_{n+3} = T_n + T_{n+1} + T_{n+2}
$$

Given an integer $(n)$, return the value of the $(n)$-th Tibonacci number $(T_n)$.

Analyse

This questions is also similar with th above two. The only difference is that the previous formula is the first two decision values, while this one is the first three decision values.

We can use dynamic programming to solve this question. The boundary conditions of Tibonacci number is $T(0) = 0$, $T(1) = 1$, $T(2) = 1$. If $n > 2$, the sum of each term is equal to the sum of the previous three terms, so there is the following recursive relationship:
$$
T(n) = T(n-1) + T(n-2) + T(n - 3)
$$

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(1)$

4. Climb Stairs Using Minimum Cost

Question Description

Now you are given an integer array cost, where cost$[i]$ is the cost to climb up to step $i$. Once you pay this cost, you can choose to climb up 1 or 2 steps.

Please calculate and return the minimum cost to reach the top of the stairs.

Analyse

The most important issue of this question is the recursion formula which can show the relationship between $dp[i]$, $dp[i-1]$ and $dp[i-2]$.

Create an array $dp$ of length $n + 1$, where $dp[i]$ represents the minimum cost to reach index $i$.

If you want to reach to the step $i$, you have two choices.

  1. 1 Step: From step $i - 1$, so the cost is $dp[i-1] + cost[i-1]$;
  2. 2 Steps: From step $i - 2$, so the cost is $dp[i-2] + cost[i -2]$;

When $2‚â§ i ‚â§ n$, we can reach index $i$ from index $i-1$ using the cost of cost$[i - 1]$, or from index $i - 2$ using the cost of cost$[i - 2]$ to reach index $i$. In order to minimize the total cost, $dp[i]$ should take the minimum of the above two items, so the state transition equation is as follows:
$$
dp[i] = min(dp[i-1]+cost[i-1],dp[i-2] + cost[i-2])
$$

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(1)$

5. Robbery

Question Description

You are a professional thief, planning to steal from houses along the street. There is a certain amount of cash hidden in each house. The only limiting factor affecting your theft is that the adjacent houses are equipped with interconnected anti-theft systems. If two adjacent houses are broken into by thieves on the same night, the system will automatically alarm.

Analyse

The most important issue of this question is ‚Äúto steal or not to steak‚Äù when facing the ith house.

There are two choices:

  1. To steal the $i$th house, so that you can not steal the ‚Äò$i-1$‚Äôth house. The total stealing amount is the sum of the maximum total amount of the first $i-2$ houses and the amount of the $i$th house;
  2. Do not steal the $i$th house, and the total amount of the theft is the maximum total amount of the first $i-1$ houses.

Choose the option with the larger total theft amount between the two options. The total theft amount corresponding to this option is the maximum total theft amount that can be stolen from the first $i$ houses.

Use $dp[i]$ to represent the maximum total theft amount that can be stolen from the first $i$ houses, then there is the following state transition equation:
$$
dp[i] = max(dp[i-2] + nums[i],dp[i-1])
$$
The boundary conditions isÔºö

$$
\begin{cases}
\text{dp}[0] = \text{nums}[0], & \text{if there is only one house, rob it} \\
\text{dp}[1] = \max(\text{nums}[0], \text{nums}[1]), & \text{if there are two houses,rob the one with the higher amount}
\end{cases}
$$

The final answer is $dp[n - 1]$, where $n$ is the length of the array.

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(n)$

  • Space Complexity: $O(1)$

6. Delete and Get Points

Question Description

You are given an array of integers $nums$ and you can perform some operations on it.

In each operations, pick any $nums[i]$, delete it and get the number of points of $nums[i]$. After that, you must delete all elements equal to $nums[i]$ - 1 and $nums[i]$+ 1.

You start with o points. Return th maximum number of points you can get by these operations.

Analyse

This question is similar to the fifth one ‚Äúrobbery‚Äù.

Storyline

After robbing three villages, the thief arrived at the fourth village to continue his heist. He noticed that the villagers here had become smarter‚Äîthe houses were shuffled, and the alarm system was more sensitive. When he tried to steal from houses with 5 coins, 6 coins, or 4 coins, the alarm would trigger. However, due to a performance issue (a ‚Äúbug‚Äù), if he stole from 5-coin houses, the alarm would not be triggered.

Aha! The thief was a programmer! So he came up with the following idea:

Robbery Strategy

  1. He cleverly sorted the list of house amounts and wrote it down in his notebook. Since he discovered the alarm system‚Äôs ‚Äúbug‚Äù, he only recorded one 5-coin house, even if there were multiple. He also noted how many such houses there were so he wouldn‚Äôt miss them during the robbery.

‚ÄãSo his notebook contained two key things:

  • A sorted list of house amounts (no duplicates!)
  • A mapping from each amount to the number of houses with that amount (he used a hash map for quick lookup)
  1. After preparing the list, he began robbing.
    Each time he robbed a house, he kept track of the maximum amount he could steal up to that point.
  • When stealing the next house, if he finds that the amount of money stolen this time is exactly equal to the amount stolen last time + 1, he will see whether the amount of money stolen from the current house plus the amount of money stolen from the previous house is greater, or the amount of money stolen from the previous house is greater.

$$
dp[i] = max(dp[i - 1], dp[i - 2] + dp[i] * m[dp[i]]);
$$

  • If the amount of money stolen from this house is greater than 1 compared to the amount stolen last time, he knows that the alarm will not be triggered, so he brings the money from last time as well.

$$
dp[i] = dp[i - 1] + dp[i] * m[dp[i]]);
$$

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: $O(nlog(n))$
  • Space Complexity: $O(n)$
